To see the impact this eDM term have on the rotational speeds, we use the data from [Ref. 13 table 2] for our Milky Way and Eq. (\ref{v2}) to plot the rotational speed of dust [see Figure 1a-1b]. We observe that a first flattening of rotational speeds occurs around $9\sim 30$ kpc but the speeds start to fall off as distance grows. Phenomenologically one can choose a fixed dotted line around the first flattening range, which is a crudest MOND estimate depending on some
galactic mass estimate. (Realistic MOND theories include an interpolating function between Newtonian acceleration and the MOND acceleration.) Alternatively the observations can be explained by a higher accumulation of matter at Newtonian orbits around 16 kpc where the eDM term is insignificant. This is where the central bulge, consisting mainly of old stars of lower luminosity to mass ratio, is located, and that these old stars provides evidence supporting a history of the accretions towards the bulge from larger distances as suggested by the eDM term. The derived mass limit in Ref.13 is $2\times 10^{42}$ kg upto 200 kpc. We assume that there is a large low luminosity galactic mass accumulation around the bulge. In our case of interest the mass estimate is taken to be $0.76 \times 10^{42}$ kg at the distance of 16 kpc to match the rotational speed which peaks at $\approx 320$ km/s. The mass estimate could be on the low side as we move towards 200 kpc due to mass distribution at larger distances between 16 kpc to 200 kpc.  With this approximation we see in Fig. 1a that the rotational speeds from Eq.(\ref{v2}) matches the observations extremely well upto 100kpc. We also note that the Newtonian theory is quite sufficient up to 200 kpc and the eDM becomes dominant at much larger distances. In Fig. 1b, with the eDM term a mass estimate below $ 2.0 \times 10^{42}$ kg (eg. $1.4\times 10^{42}$kg) is enough to account for the observed rotational speed at 200 kpc.  We also expect another eDM induced flattening of rotational curve from 300 kpc onward toward an upper bound value of 97 km/s given by a current Milky Way mass estimate of $3 \times 10^{42}$ kg upto 2 Mpc which is the cut-off distance given in Eq.(3.10).  We have neglected the $\ddot{a}/a$ term for simplicity. We see that the eDM can produce a flatten rotational curve at large distances, but the famous first flatten curve at $9\sim 30$ kpc is only caused indirectly by the the eDM modification to the Newton's law. (We also calculate the Mercury perihelion advance rate due to this eDM resulting in $\sim O( 10^{-3})$ arcsec per century, which is much less than the 41 arcsec per century due to the relativistic correction term. Therefore the eDM effect will be insignifcant in solar system gravity considerations.) From Fig. 1b the cut-off distance restrains the thick solid line due to Eq.(\ref{v3}) to stay close to the MOND estimate at $v^4 =GMa_0$, ensuring MOND's success in galactic considerations. \\
However, the average MOND-eDM velocity gap varies with the parameters of the galaxy. In general, the total mass, the mass density distributions and the angular momentum per unit mass are the relevant parameters leading to rotational curves of different shapes. For example in Old elliptical galaxy, most of the mass concentration is within the bulge, in practice observable rotational curves will not be far from the bulge. The MOND-eDM velocity gap depends on the total mass inside the bulge. The smaller the total mass, the $H$ dependent eDM becomes effective at a shorter radius with a smaller cut-off radius and thus the MOND-eDM gap will be smaller. One could still see the eDM halo from lensing observations. For a Young galaxy with an uniform gas mass distribution, we expect that the eDM will enhance the gravitational potentially uniformly throughout the gas radius and starts to increase outside the gas radius towards the cut-off. And the smaller total gas mass (and the larger the angular momentum per unit mass), the smaller the cut-off radius, the smaller the eDM-MOND gap and the size of observable halo will be smaller and weaker. \\\\

We see that the eDM can produce a flatten rotational curve at large distances, but the famous first flatten curve at $9\sim 30$ kpc is only caused indirectly by the the eDM modification to the Newton's law. (We also calculate the Mercury perihelion advance rate due to this eDM resulting in $\sim O( 10^{-3})$ arcsec per century, which is much less than the 41 arcsec per century due to the relativistic correction term. Therefore the eDM effect will be insignifcant in solar system gravity considerations.) From Fig. 1b the cut-off distance restrains the thick solid line due to Eq.(\ref{v3}) to stay close to the MOND estimate at $v^4 =GMa_0$, ensuring MOND's success in galactic considerations. \\
However, the average MOND-eDM velocity gap varies with the parameters of the galaxy. In general, the total mass, the mass density distributions and the angular momentum per unit mass are the relevant parameters leading to rotational curves of different shapes. For example in Old elliptical galaxy, most of the mass concentration is within the bulge, in practice observable rotational curves will not be far from the bulge. The MOND-eDM velocity gap depends on the total mass inside the bulge. The smaller the total mass, the $H$ dependent eDM becomes effective at a shorter radius with a smaller cut-off radius and thus the MOND-eDM gap will be smaller. One could still see the eDM halo from lensing observations. For a Young galaxy with an uniform gas mass distribution, we expect that the eDM will enhance the gravitational potentially uniformly throughout the gas radius and starts to increase outside the gas radius towards the cut-off. And the smaller total gas mass (and the larger the angular momentum per unit mass), the smaller the cut-off radius, the smaller the eDM-MOND gap and the size of observable halo will be smaller and weaker. \\\\

\section{Summary}
The issues around the nature of dark matter remains unresolved.  With no modification of Einstein Gravity, we find that in a Single-metric approach for a spherical symmetric region with central mass concentration in the FRW background to possess an eDM term in the slow speed limit of its particle equation of motion. This solution has no free parameter and the eDM term has a built-in dependence on the Hubble parameter. This eDM density can vary from being a large factor of an uniform mass density in an overdense region in the matter dominant epoch to becoming a massive halo density in the dark energy dominant epoch. The eDM comes from the time-time component of the momentum stress tensor and plays the role of enhanced matter density throughout the Universe's history so it should cause lensing similar to baryonic matter. We show how this new eDM term can account for the observations which motivate the need for dark matter in different epochs and could provide answers for other difficulties that is not fully explained by MOND. \\
